message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient fell on his left elbow, which suggests a nerve injury. The absence of pinprick sensation in the left 5th digit and medial aspect of the left 4th digit suggests an ulnar neuropathy. Axillary neuropathy affects the deltoid muscle and radial neuropathy affects the extensor muscles. Median neuropathy affects the thumb, index and middle fingers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of pinprick sensation absence in the medial aspect of the fourth digit and the fifth digit suggest ulnar neuropathy. The mechanism of injury to the elbow is consistent with a cubital tunnel syndrome or an ulnar collateral ligament injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient fell onto his left elbow, and the absence of sensation in the 5th digit and medial aspect of the 4th digit suggests ulnar neuropathy. Axillary neuropathy involves the shoulder, radial neuropathy involves the posterior arm and hand, and median neuropathy involves the thumb, index, and middle fingers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of absent pinprick sensation in the 5th digit and medial aspect of the 4th digit suggest an ulnar neuropathy, which can be caused by trauma to the elbow or compression of the ulnar nerve. None of the other options would cause numbness in this distribution.

We refer to medical resources for help. The location of the absent pinprick sensation, on the medial aspect of the left 4th digit and the left 5th digit, suggests involvement of the ulnar nerve. This injury is possible in cases of elbow trauma, such as a fall onto the elbow, and can cause symptoms such as numbness or weakness in the hand and fingers. Options A, B, and C are less likely based on the distribution of the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing loss of sensation in the ulnar nerve distribution, which suggests ulnar neuropathy. The mechanism of injury, falling directly onto the elbow, is consistent with a possible cubital tunnel syndrome or ulnar fracture causing entrapment or compression of the ulnar nerve. Axillary neuropathy would affect the shoulder, radial neuropathy would cause wrist drop and sensory loss on the dorsal hand and forearm, and median neuropathy would cause sensory loss in the lateral 3.5 digits and weakness or atrophy of the thumb, index, and middle fingers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the absent pinprick sensation, along with the mechanism of injury, suggests ulnar neuropathy. Axillary neuropathy would result in sensory loss of the lateral aspect of the shoulder. Radial neuropathy would result in sensory loss on the dorsal aspect of the hand and forearm. Median neuropathy would result in sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the hand and fingers 1-3.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including sudden intense pain, inability to move the elbow, and absent pinprick sensation in specific areas, suggest ulnar neuropathy. Axillary neuropathy affects the shoulder and radial neuropathy affects the posterior arm and forearm. Median neuropathy affects the anterior forearm and hand but not the specific areas described in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest ulnar neuropathy, which affects the sensory function of the 5th and medial aspect of the 4th digit. The mechanism of injury, a fall directly onto the elbow, can cause compression or traction injury to the ulnar nerve. None of the other options would cause the specific sensory deficits described in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pinprick sensation absence in the left 5th digit and the medial aspect of the left 4th digit suggest ulnar neuropathy, which can occur due to trauma to the elbow. Axillary neuropathy would present with weakness in abduction of the arm, while radial neuropathy would affect the wrist and digits in extension. Median neuropathy would affect the thumb, index finger, and middle finger.
